body.p: "Two Rivulets," joined with "Leaves of Grass," may be summed up as the result of twenty years labor, & the attempt into a new unrhymed but rhythmical expression the events, & still more the spirit of those years, with all their tremendous developements of war, peace, inventions, science—and the advent of America and republicanism. For such may be called the general aim of this author, although every thing in both volumes revolves around the central human personality. The Body and the Soul are one, & in the latter the former is immortal. Thus the principal underlying & elementary qualities of all Whitman's writings are, a powerful sense of physical perfection, size, health, strength & beauty, with great amativeness,adhesiveness, a wonderfully buoyant joyousness of spirit, and immortality, not as an intellection, but as a pervading instinct. With these comes forward far more prominently in "Two Rivulets," than in the

preceding volume, the moral law, the “inner light” of the Quakers, the pure conscience, rising over all the rest like pinnacles to some elaborated building. We have too the indestructibility of the Union, the radical equality of the sexes, (not at all from the “woman’s rights” point of view, however,) & the duties of these men & women, as practical citizens, to the National, State, & municipal governments

Undoubtedly this book could never have been written—neither
its the
prose or verse—except for the Secession War. We do not mean its mere material statements or themes, but in its spirit its tints & half‑tints, its singular, almost gloating pride & patriotism & Nationality, the subtle bouquet palpable enough in every page to him or her who has the palate & nostril to catch it; and even in that negative feature of the great masters which Schiller celebrates,
"
For Most
the great artist we behold,
In what his art leaves—just untold,"
—the entire work is
perhaps best finally
to be considered at as we have understood, Walt Whitman’s intimate friends know it to be; the result of the war. as, we understand, the author himself markedly claims it to be, from his point of view, the first characteristic literary result of the war.

with this we take our leave of these utterances and their author. Their position in literature remains yet to be tried and established, for there is not no denying that they are opposed to most of all the literary and art‑laws, & many of the decorums, established by the best intellects of all civilized lands, all ages, yet they are perhaps the hottest & most vitalised pulsations of living, loving blood yet thrown into literature, and their roots are democratic, American and modern, far beyond any thus known. There is no denying that patriotism, Their patriotism is of a vehemence yet not hitherto unknown in American authorship. Then Whitman has a fond confidence that he will yet be absorbed and appreciated by his country. He says:
From my last years, last thoughts I here bequeath,
Scatter’d and dropt, in seeds, and wafted to the West,
Through moisture of Ohio, prairie soil of Illinois—through
Colorado, California air,
For Time to germinate fully.
